items.summary: A decline in face-to-face banking services and cash facilities is harming some Australians more than others, advocates say.

items.title: KISS founding member and lead guitarist Ace Frehley dies at 74
items.summary: Ace Frehley, founding member of the glam rock band KISS, has died at 74 after complications following a recent fall.

items.title: Fears grow over truce's fragility amid concerns around hostages bodies, aid
items.summary: Israel is pressing Hamas to honour the ceasefire agreement and return the bodies of hostages still held in Gaza. This comes as satellite images show limited aid convoys entering the enclave through Kerem Shalom, while displaced Palestinians in Khan Younis endure worsening living conditions amid shortages of food, fuel, and clean water. With more than 67,900 Palestinians killed since 2023 and uncertainty over Rafah’s reopening, fears are growing that the fragile truce could collapse.

items.summary: Contingency plans developed for sending Australian troops to help secure peace in Gaza; Australia signs a tax treaty with Ukraine; and in the AFL, Western Bulldogs star Jamarra Ugle-Hagan heads the Gold Coast Suns.

items.title: Vatican report says clergy sex abuse victims need reparations and tangible sanctions to heal
items.summary: An internal Vatican report has delivered scathing criticism of the Catholic Church's handling of decades of allegations of sexual abuse from around the world. It's calling for financial reparations and sanctions for abusers and their enablers. AND A WARNING THAT THE CONTENT OF THIS STORY MAY BE DISTRESSING FOR SOME LISTENERS

items.title: Government considering offshore recognition of migrant skills
items.summary: Home Affairs Minister Tony Burke says the government is working on the possibility of an offshore recognition of skills. He says this will help save time and money for skilled migrants looking to move to Australia. In his address the Press Club in Canberra Mr Burke also flagged changes to inactive bank accounts to combat money laundering.

items.title: Trump says he will meet Putin to discuss Ukraine war after 'great progress' in call
items.summary: Donald Trump said he and Vladimir Putin would meet to discuss if they can bring the "inglorious" war to an end.

items.title: Yeah, nah: Australians report a drop in their sense of belonging
items.summary: Australians' sense of belonging has been declining over time. That's the major finding from this year's social cohesion report, from the Scanlon Foundation Research Institute. But while the report suggests there is ongoing strain in peoples' sense of belonging, trust, and identity, the Foundation remains optimistic, saying most Australians still report happiness and a strong sense of community.

items.title: 'Degraded and uneasy': Incarcerated trans women push back on NT prison ban proposal
items.summary: Trans women prisoners are most at risk of violence, advocates say, hitting back at the NT chief minister's recent claims.

items.summary: New powers announced to combat terrorism financing and crime related to crypto ATMs; Australia's unemployment rate rises to 4.5 per cent; and in sport, tributes for Ariarne Titmus after she announces her immediate retirement from competitive swimming.

items.title: Germany, NATO pledge billions in new Ukraine aid as Russia reels from fuel strikes
items.summary: Germany and NATO allies have pledged billions in new aid to Ukraine as the war nears its fourth winter, with Kyiv urging urgent air-defence support amid a sharp drop in foreign assistance. Meanwhile, Russia is grappling with fuel shortages following Ukrainian strikes, as President Donald Trump renews his criticism of Vladimir Putin over the prolonged conflict and Russia’s faltering economy.

items.title: Hamas-Israel ceasefire holds - but only just
items.summary: Two more bodies of deceased hostages have been handed over to the Red Cross by Hamas, following Israel's accusation that the militant group were failing to abide by the terms of the ceasefire deal. Aid is continuing to roll into Gaza despite threats from Israel that they would cut supplies and close border crossings. But there are heightened concerns for the fragile ceasefire, amid reports US President Donald Trump is considering allowing Israel to resume its military activities.

items.title: Trump confirms he authorised covert CIA operations in Venezuela

items.title: Is your job burning you out? Experts say better boundaries and workplace connections can help
items.summary: Despite a growing awareness around mental health, research shows burnout in the workplace is still a major challenge. Experts say without proper training and healthy boundaries in the workplace, more and more Australians will consider leaving their jobs in the next year.

items.summary: A new study has found Queensland's tropical rainforests emit more carbon than they absorb, raising concerns for Australia's climate targets.

items.title: NSW hits 'grim milestone' with First Nations deaths in custody reaching record levels
items.summary: The New South Wales coroner says the state has hit a grim milestone with First Nations deaths in custody reaching record levels. 12 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have died in custody in the state this year, the highest number ever recorded in a single year. The distressing figures have prompted the state coroner to issue a rare public statement, condemning the deaths and vowing to investigate each one independently and thoroughly.

items.title: Labor criticised over worker visa rule backflip that could affect thousands

items.title: 'La Crise': French politics stumbles from crisis to crisis
items.summary: The Eurozone's second-largest economy is battling a deep political crisis. It all started when French President Emmanuel Macron called snap elections last year in an attempt to consolidate his power. Instead, they resulted in a hung parliament and gains for the far right. Now, France’s sixth prime minister in under two years has been forced to abandon one of the president’s key achievements just to hold his government together.

items.title: Victorian government debates ground-breaking Treaty Bill
items.summary: The Victorian Government is debating a historic Statewide Treaty Bill, establishing Australia's first ever Treaty agreement between a state government and First Peoples in Victoria. If signed into law, the Treaty Bill will forge a path forward for First Peoples in Victoria to negotiate and influence the policy that affects community.

In Melbourne, Israeli hostage supporters took to the streets while there's also been celebration among families of Palestinians set free.

items.title: Middle East peace deal signed; so where to from here?
items.summary: World leaders have signed a historic Middle East deal at a summit in Egypt. It comes hours after Israel and Hamas exchanged detainees and hostages. Israel released nearly 2,000 Palestinians from Israeli prisons, and Gaza released the surviving Israeli hostages after two years in captivity.

items.title: Climate tipping points being crossed, scientists warn
items.summary: A large white coral reef containing important species and fossil traces has been discovered at a depth of more than 500 metres in the Gulf of Naples, in a rare discovery for the Mediterranean. But a new report suggests reefs like this might already be in danger, with global warming crossing dangerous thresholds sooner than expected and the world's coral reefs now in an almost irreversible die-off. It marks what scientists are describing as the first tipping point in climate-driven ecosystem collapse.

items.title: Joyful reunions for families in Israel, Gaza | Midday News Bulletin 14 October 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, scenes of jubilation as Israeli hostages and Palestinian prisoners return home, the United Nations urges leaders to use the momentum of the exchange to create peace in Gaza. And in football, Spain plans to continue its winning streak as it strives for World Cup qualification.

items.title: The new threat to Australia's potato industry - what is it and how can we deal with it?
items.summary: Of all Australian states, Tasmania is the biggest producer of potatoes, and a lot of what's grown here goes into potato products you would know well – hot chips, hash browns and wedges among them. But a new virus detected in recent months is causing concern. Growers are optimistic it can be managed, stressing it doesn't pose a risk to human health.

items.title: ‘Historic exchange’: all Israeli hostages freed as Gaza peace talks continue
items.summary: All 20 surviving Israeli hostages have been released from Hamas captivity in Gaza in a historic exchange as part of the first phase of a Gaza peace plan. And nearly 2000 Palestinians have also been freed from Israeli prisons, with the majority headed back to the war-ravaged Palestinian enclave. United States President Donald Trump has claimed the Israel-Hamas war is over, but negotiations are set to continue in Egypt with long-term peace still far from secure.

items.title: Why doesn't Australia have a national Human Rights Act?
items.summary: Human right law experts are calling the federal government to take what they call a significant opportunity to establish a federal Human Rights Act. It comes as a new report analyses how attempts to create such an act in Australia over five decades has been met with political opposition and misinformation.

United States President Donald Trump and Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi are to co-host a Gaza peace summit in Egypt, where more than 20 world leaders are expected to back plans to achieve a lasting peace.

items.title: Dozens killed as Pakistan–Afghanistan border clashes escalate
items.summary: Dozens of fighters have been killed in overnight border clashes between Pakistan and Afghanistan in the most serious fighting between the neighbours since the Taliban came to power in Kabul. Tensions have risen after Pakistan demanded the Taliban take action against militants who have stepped up attacks in Pakistan, saying they operate from bases in Afghanistan. The Taliban denies that Pakistani militants are present on its soil.

This comes as the government announced a $9.5 million funding package in May last year to improve awareness and support for early pregnancy loss.

items.title: California sends ultraprocessed school meals to the sin bin
items.summary: California is to phase out certain ultraprocessed foods from school meals over the next decade under a first-in-the-nation law signed by Governor Gavin Newsom. Schools will have to start removing those foods from their menus by July 2029, and districts will be barred from selling them for breakfast or lunch by July 2035.

items.title: US aid cuts start to bite for Myanmar's refugees
items.summary: Earlier this year, US President Donald Trump ordered steep cuts to the US foreign aid budget, a move that sparked concerns it would cause widespread harm and even deaths for the millions that relied on the programs delivered or funded by the USAid office. Now, refugees and advocates say the cuts are starting to bite, with 85 per cent of residents in refugee camps along the Myanmar-Thai border living without USAid food rations.

items.title: The looming Europe travel change that will affect Australians
items.summary: New personal data collection rules are about to come into effect in Europe's Schengen area. Here's what you need to know.

items.title: How a 'deeply-embedded' part of Australian culture could change forever
items.summary: Young Australians are leading this emerging generational shift, according to a new study.

items.title: Unveiled: New 60-day plan for Gaza after ceasefire begins
items.summary: The United Nations says it's prepared for a humanitarian aid "surge" once the Gaza ceasefire begins.

items.title: Tsunami threat passes after powerful earthquake strikes Philippines
items.summary: A tsunami alert for the Philippines, Palau and Indonesia has been lifted following a magnitude 7.4 earthquake south of the Philippines.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 10 October 2025
items.summary: A daily news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Peace in the Middle East greeted with joy across the divide
items.summary: After two years of devastating conflict, there are scenes of cautious celebration across the Middle East. A historic ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas, brokered by US President Donald Trump, has been reached, in effect, marking what some are calling a new chapter of peace.

items.title: Are Syria’s first post-Assad elections strengthening or weakening democracy?
items.summary: Syria's first parliamentary elections since the fall of Bashar al-Assad have sparked criticism for how they were run. The election was seen as a key step in the shift away from the al-Assad regime, but one that has sparked concerns about inclusivity and fairness under the country's new leaders. Syrians here in Australia say their relatives at home do not feel represented by the new Government.

items.title: Phase one of Gaza peace deal set to begin after approval by Israeli cabinet
items.summary: Despite celebrations in Israel and Gaza and a flood of messages from world leaders hailing the deal, numerous issues remain unsettled.

items.title: 'Safe beds save lives': Calls for urgent action to address rising number of homeless women
items.summary: Australians are being urged to recognise the link between domestic violence and homelessness, as more women face sleeping rough.

items.title: What’s the Senate actually estimating? Ft. David Pocock
items.summary: The first senate estimates of the 48th Parliament have arrived – where the Albanese Labor Government and representatives from the Australian Public Service and government agencies are quizzed for up to 14 hours a day about pretty much anything. It’s tedious, it’s long, but it’s all about accountability, and Independent Senator for the ACT David Pocock takes us behind the scenes. Plus Bob Katter has a suggestion for the footy off-season, and Andrew Hastie has left the Coalition front bench.

items.title: 'It felt like home': Why generations of migrant Australians love the NPL
items.summary: Once the lifeblood of migrant communities, suburban football clubs are back on the national stage for the Australian Championship.

items.title: Fear drove Fouad to Australia. Even after a major milestone, his hopes are dim
items.summary: Fouad Berzghal's home country had its first election since the fall of its dictator. But there are questions over how much will change.

items.title: A Gaza peace deal signed; au revoir to yet another French PM; & Australia's new security alliance
items.summary: Hamas and Israel sign up for Phase One of Trump's new 20-point plan for peace in Gaza. France's revolving door on its prime ministerial office takes another spin. Plus Australia and PNG sign on to an expanded alliance for regional cooperation. And how desperate for $5,000 are you? Take a job at a haunted hotel desperate?

items.title: Gaza peace deal market impacts & Gemini crypto exchange enters Australia
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Robert Talevski to see how the Gaza peace deal has impacted markets; and Ricardo takes a look at Australia's crypto regulatory space with Gemini's Saad Ahmed.

items.title: The common mortgage feature that could be leaving you 'worse off'
items.summary: Mortgage offset accounts have helped many Australians wipe interest off their home loan. But they don't always offer a benefit.

items.title: New workplace laws aim to remove extra pain burden on parents arising from stillbirth
items.summary: Laws have been introduced into federal parliament to stop employers from scrapping leave entitlements when families face the tragedy of a stillbirth or death of their baby.

items.title: The Gaza peace deal's first phase has been agreed to. But there are still many questions
items.summary: Despite the hopes raised for ending the war, crucial details are yet to be spelled out.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 9 October 2025
items.summary: A daily news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: What we've learnt about the 'ISIS brides', as federal police anticipate more returns
items.summary: The Australian Federal Police said the group, which has returned from Syria, was being monitored as part of an ongoing operation.

items.title: Could Donald Trump win the 2025 Nobel Peace Prize?
items.summary: Leaders seeking to curry favour with Trump have been quick to talk up the US president's chances, but experts aren't so sure.

items.title: Prison guards thought TJ was 'playing possum'. Hours later, he was dead
items.summary: TJ's death in custody prompted an apology by Corrective Services NSW. But did he ever stand a chance of leaving?

items.title: 'Deeply harmful': Autism advocates fear major change for some Australian children
items.summary: The government is pushing ahead with a new program — and there are concerns it could leave some children falling between the cracks.

items.title: There's a difference between hot and cold sweat — and one tends to smell more distinctive
items.summary: Cold sweat is known as psychological sweat, while hot sweat is often the body's response to physical exertion.

items.title: Communications minister accused of misleading parliament over Optus notification
items.summary: The federal opposition has accused Communications Minister Anika Wells of misleading parliament over when her office was notified of the Optus Triple-Zero outage that has been linked to four deaths. It comes as emails that Optus sent to notify the government and the regulator of the outages, which ultimately affected more than 600 people last month, are scrutinised in Senate estimates. Meanwhile, legislation creating a triple-zero custodian has passed the lower house.

items.title: Gold breaks US$4,000 & is NZ becoming a better value tourist destination?
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Armina Rosenberg from Minotaur Capital about the day's market action, including gold's new milestone and how her firm is using AI to invest; plus Nick Tuffley from ASB Bank goes through why the RBNZ cut interest rates more than expected and what it means for Australian travellers going to New Zealand.

items.title: Australia's cancer survival rates are improving — but there are also some 'concerning' trends
items.summary: Australia's latest snapshot of cancer incidence and deaths has been released.

items.title: Australian flotilla activist accuses government of 'shameful' Israel extraction effort
items.summary: Australians were detained at what has been called an "outrageous" prison.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 8 October 2025
items.summary: A daily news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Home Affairs knew for months 'ISIS brides' were returning; granted children citizenship
items.summary: The federal government says the group, who arrived in Australia recently, are being monitored.

items.title: Minister urged to 'come clean' on NDIS changes, as advocates fear 'degrading' treatment
items.summary: Disability advocates are demanding clarity on upcoming NDIS changes, warning that the new system could be "traumatising".

items.title: Government fast-tracks legislation to strengthen 000 call system
items.summary: The government has fast-tracked legislation into parliament aimed at strengthening the 000 call system after failures by Optus to ensure access to emergency calls. As parliament resumed, the nation's leaders made time to commemorate the second anniversary of the October 7 attack on Israel by Hamas.

items.title: ASIC approves ASX listing market competitor; is AI in a bubble? and gold approaches US$4,000
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Todd Hoare from LGT Wealth Management Australia Management about the day's sharemarket action, including ASIC's approval of Cboe Australia's listing market.

items.title: GP snapshot reveals why the job has become more complicated
items.summary: A snapshot of Australian general practice has revealed that GPs are having to see patients for longer appointments to treat more complex medical needs. The Health of the Nation industry survey of almost 2,500 GPs also shows a growing number of general practitioners are managing patient conditions typically handled by specialists.

items.title: 'The purpose of my voice is to teach history': Survivor tells how a party turned to trauma
items.summary: Nova Festival attack survivor Natalie Sanandaji shares her ordeal escaping the massacre on 7 October 2023 in southern Israel.

items.title: Federal government admits handballing truth-telling process as only 'half a person' employed
items.summary: The Greens have questioned what progress is being made on truth-telling and treaty at a federal level.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 7 October 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Advocates alarmed as major change for autistic kids looms
items.summary: There are fears that many children with autism or learning difficulties will fall between the cracks of a new support system that aims to limit access to the National Disability Insurance Scheme. The Thriving Kids initiative will be rolled out from the middle of next year, with a focus on providing support to children with so-called mild to moderate autism within community and mainstream settings. But disability advocates have told a parliamentary inquiry it is these children that are most often overlooked or misunderstood.

items.title: University students panicked after fraudulent emails 'revoked', 'disqualified' degrees
items.summary: Western Sydney University said the emails are "not legitimate" and have been reported to police.

items.title: Gaza peace talks to continue as October 7 anniversary marked by commemoration, protests
items.summary: As Gaza marks two years under devastating Israeli bombardment, commemorations of the October 7 attacks and demonstrations in support of Palestinians are planned around the world.

items.title: Australians from Gaza aid flotilla deported by Israel to Jordan following detention
items.summary: Some of the Australian activists recently detained by Israel have alleged violence and mistreatment at the hands of soldiers.

items.title: The unseen impact of missing or damaged teeth — and the key to addressing it
items.summary: Why is it so shameful to have missing teeth or gum disease? And what can we do about it?

items.title: 'Fighting a war on two fronts': Behind the rise of a new threat in Gaza
items.summary: Newly released data shows a major spike in intra-Palestinian violent incidents this year, as well as a significant rise in stolen aid packages.

items.title: Gold and copper prices surge and why you shouldn’t ignore your annual super statement
items.summary: The ASX-200 has started the week in the red, as a tech sell-off offset strong gains by gold and copper miners. Plus, Japanese stocks have hit a record high just a day after the country’s ruling Liberal Democratic Party named Sanae Takaichi as its leader. For more, Rena Sarumpaet spoke with George Boubouras from K2 Asset Management. As annual superannuation statements start to arrive in the mail, Australians are being urged to not ignore them with research from Canstar showing about a fifth of respondents only check their super once every few years - or never. For more on how a financial health check could benefit your nest egg, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Canstar Data Insights Director Sally Tindall.

items.title: Australian claims dislocated arm from soldiers in prison called Israel's 'worst'
items.summary: Ketziot prison was once called the "largest and the worst" of Israel's prisons by Human Rights Watch. There are welfare concerns for Australians detained there.

items.title: "Excitement, then everything changed": survivors remember October 7 attack as calls grow for end to Gaza war
items.summary: Thousands of Australians are joining vigils across the nation to mark the second anniversary of the deadly Hamas attack on Israel. Around 1200 people were killed and 250 taken hostage during the designated terror group's attack on October 7, 2023, which triggered a brutal military response from Israel.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 6 October 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: The Australians who think it's fine to steal, and those who disagree
items.summary: A new survey found a generational divide when it comes to rationalising retail theft behaviours, including scanning items incorrectly at self-checkout.

items.title: It's on Australia's 'do not travel' list. But influencers are promoting it anyway
items.summary: A surge of travel vloggers is putting Afghanistan back on the tourism map, even as the Taliban tightens restrictions on women and security risks remain high.

items.title: Zelenskyy criticises world 'silence' after yet another large-scale Russian attack
items.summary: Five people have died after the Russian military attacked Ukraine overnight with 53 missiles and several waves of drones.

items.title: 'We do not see any change': Israel pounds Gaza despite Trump's call for end to bombing
items.summary: There was no let-up in Israeli attacks on Gaza over the weekend as planes and tanks pounded areas across the enclave.

items.title: Israelis like Michal and Yarden act as 'human shields' in the West Bank. They've been called traitors
items.summary: As the second anniversary of October 7 and Israel’s war in Gaza approaches, settler violence in the West Bank is steadily escalating. A small number of Israelis like Yarden want to end the 'status quo' — and they're willing to act as human shields to achieve it.

items.title: We now know when your HECS debt will be slashed, and by how much
items.summary: About three million Australians with a student debt will soon see their balance owed reduced.

items.title: 'Determination and ingenuity': Australia's oldest man just turned 112
items.summary: Ken Weeks was still walking into town for shopping after he turned 100 more than a decade ago.

items.title: Location-tracking apps: A harmful invasion of privacy or a great tool to keep loved ones safe?
items.summary: With consent, location-tracking can be immensely useful in some situations, experts say, but they warn that the technology is certainly not without potential harms and can lead to controlling and coercive behaviours.

items.title: Smooth Snake slithering its way back to life in the UK
items.summary: Snakes may be ten a penny here in Australia but in the UK it's a different story. Britain's rarest reptile, known as the Smooth Snake, is thriving again after conservation efforts were introduced to save it in 2009. But monitoring exactly how many Smooth Snakes there are can be a challenge due to the reptile's reclusive nature.

items.title: Yazidi refugees in Toowoomba find community through hockey
items.summary: The Queensland city of Toowoomba has become home to thousands of Yazidi refugees. A local hockey program is aiming to develop confidence and language skills for this community, with the help of retired locals on the field.

items.title: 'I passed out multiple times at work': The health problem costing Australia billions
items.summary: Endometriosis affects one in seven Australian women, yet experts warn workplaces remain years behind in providing support for those living with this "invisible" condition.

items.title: The major sticking points that could still upend the partially accepted Gaza peace deal
items.summary: One expert says a hostage-prisoner exchange between Israel and Hamas is "highly likely" to go ahead, but he and others remain wary about the prospects for other parts of a Gaza peace deal.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Could a First Nations voice help tackle stubborn public health challenges?
items.summary: Nearly two years after the failed referendum saw a First Nations voice to parliament shot down, some NGOs and state governments have been taking the initiative to follow the wishes of the majority of Indigenous communities in Australia who voted for this special representation. Australia's principal non-government organisation for public health, the Public Health Association of Australia, has announced they will be instituting an Aboriginal and Torres-Strait Islander voice to help guide their work after a near unanimous vote by their members. SBS spoke to Dr Summer May Finlay, a Yorta Yorta woman, an Associate Professor at the University of Wollongong and the Vice President (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander) of the Public Health Association about the importance of a First Nations voice in helping to Close the Gap on healthcare outcomes between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians

items.title: 700 Australians were recruited for a yoga study. What researchers found surprised them
items.summary: Many older Australians who practice yoga say it gives them strength and confidence, but a new study suggests one particular type of yoga could be associated with a higher risk of falls.

items.title: 'The 99 per cent are not your enemy': Genesis Owusu on power, politics and racism
items.summary: Genesis Owusu has battled racism, depression and industry pressures — but his third album is his most direct yet. He says it’s a blunt call for truth in an era of division.

items.title: Oil prices tumble to 4 month low as ASX edges closer to record high
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Dianne Colledge from Morgans Financial Limited about the days sharemarket action including the opportunites for investors.

items.title: Forwards or backwards? Daylight saving starts soon — here's what to know
items.summary: Here's everything you need to know, including tips on how to adjust.

items.title: Footy, culture, and so much more: welcome to the Koori knockout
items.summary: This weekend will see the largest annual gathering of Indigenous people in the country at the New South Wales Koori knockout rugby league tournament. It's a sporting competition... but also, so much more.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 3 October 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: New trick Australians are using to 'maximise' tax returns — but beware of the risks
items.summary: It might be free to use and readily available, but it could also be giving incorrect advice.

items.title: Why experts are 'rewriting' Australia's bushfire risk this summer
items.summary: Unusual weather patterns and climate change are raising concerns for parts of Australia, as well as popular travel destinations.

items.title: ASX rallies despite US government shutdown
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Callam Pickering about the latest household spending data and what it means for interest rates, plus Henry Jennings from Marcus Today on the days market action.

items.title: NIMBYs, YIMBYs — and BIMBYs: The new group in Australia's housing stoush
items.summary: As state governments roll out plans to battle Australia's housing crisis, community groups are mobilising to have a say in how their suburbs are — or are not — changed.

items.title: Nuclear energy sank the Coalition at the election — can it power their comeback?
items.summary: The coalition are revamping their proposal for nuclear energy, despite suffering an election loss with this policy. The details are yet to be confirmed, but the Opposition Energy Minister says they will adapt their plan to meet developments in the space.

items.title: Gaza peace plan, US shuts down & China combats whingers
items.summary: A new 20-point plan for peace in Gaza gains support among the international community. Trump warns the US military of the enemy from within as Hegseth tells Generals to slim down for the war on woke. Plus, Democrats and Republicans point the finger at each other as the US government shuts down. Also, Moscow warns of a new red line in the war in Ukraine. And, China launches a campaign to stamp out online negativity.

items.title: Australian men face loneliness crisis: what’s driving it and how to fix it
items.summary: Loneliness among men has been described as a "crisis" in Australia, and it appears to be on the rise. This social isolation can not only hurt mens mental health and overall wellbeing, it is also costing the Australian economy billions of dollars. A recent Australian study could hold the answer as to why men appear to be stuggling more with loneliness.

items.title: Animal shelter accused of having 'blood on its hands' after euthanising 12-week-old puppy
items.summary: A couple who had fostered the dog, Murphy, had called Victoria's Lost Dogs Home to ask how he was going, only to be told he would be put down.
